Albert Einstein.passage: Albert Einstein (14 March 1879 – 18 April 1955) was a German-born theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity, one of the two pillars of modern physics (alongside quantum mechanics). His work is also known for its influence on the philosophy of science. He is best known to the general public for his mass–energy equivalence formula E = mc^2, which has been dubbed "the world's most famous equation". He received the 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics "for his services to Theoretical Physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect". Near the beginning of his career, Einstein thought that Newtonian mechanics was no longer enough to reconcile the laws of classical mechanics with the laws of the electromagnetic field. This led him to develop his special theory of relativity during his time at the Swiss Patent Office in Bern (1902–1909). However, he realized that the principle of relativity could also be extended to gravitational fields, and he published a paper on general relativity in 1916 introducing his theory of gravitation. He continued to deal with problems of statistical mechanics and quantum theory, which led to his explanations of particle theory and the motion of molecules. He also investigated the thermal properties of light which laid the foundation of the photon theory of light. In 1917, Einstein applied the general theory of relativity to model the structure of the universe as a whole. He was visiting the United States when Adolf Hitler came to power in 1933 and, being Jewish, did not go back to Germany, where he had been a professor at the Berlin Academy of Sciences. He settled in the United States, becoming an American citizen in 1940. On the eve of World War II, he endorsed a letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt alerting him to the potential development of "extremely powerful bombs of a new type" and recommending that the U.S. begin similar research. This eventually led to what would become the Manhattan Project. Einstein supported defending the Allied forces, but largely denounced using the new discovery of nuclear fission as a weapon. Later, with the British philosopher Bertrand Russell, Einstein signed the Russell–Einstein Manifesto, which highlighted the danger of nuclear weapons. Einstein was affiliated with the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, until his death in 1955.

Marie Curie.passage: Marie Curie (1867-1934) was a Polish-born physicist and chemist who made groundbreaking contributions to the field of radioactivity. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields. Born Maria Skłodowska in Warsaw, Poland, Curie was the youngest of five children. Her parents were both teachers, and they instilled in her a love of learning from a young age. Despite facing discrimination as a woman and a foreigner, Curie excelled in her studies and eventually earned a degree in physics from the Sorbonne in Paris. In 1895, Curie married Pierre Curie, a fellow physicist, and the two began working together on the study of radioactivity. They discovered two new elements, polonium and radium, and developed techniques for isolating and measuring radioactivity. Their work revolutionized the field of physics and chemistry, and earned them the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903. After Pierre's death in 1906, Curie continued her research and teaching, becoming the first woman to teach at the Sorbonne. She also founded the Radium Institute in Paris, which became a center for research on radioactivity. In 1911, Curie won her second Nobel Prize, this time in Chemistry, for her discovery of radium and polonium. She was the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields, and remains one of only four people to have achieved this feat. Throughout her career, Curie faced discrimination and sexism, but she remained dedicated to her work and her passion for science. She died in 1934 from complications related to her exposure to radiation, but her legacy lives on as a pioneer in the field of radioactivity and a role model for women in science.

Isaac Newton.passage: Sir Isaac Newton (25 December 1642 – 20 March 1726/27) was an English mathematician, physicist, astronomer, theologian, and author who is widely recognised as one of the most influential scientists of all time and as a key figure in the scientific revolution. His book Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica (Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy), first published in 1687, laid the foundations of classical mechanics. Newton also made seminal contributions to optics, and shares credit with Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz for developing the infinitesimal calculus. In Principia, Newton formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation that formed the dominant scientific viewpoint until it was superseded by the theory of relativity. Newton used his mathematical description of gravity to prove Kepler's laws of planetary motion, account for tides, the trajectories of comets, the precession of the equinoxes and other phenomena, eradicating doubt about the Solar System's heliocentricity. He demonstrated that the motion of objects on Earth and celestial bodies could be accounted for by the same principles. Newton's inference that the Earth is an oblate spheroid was later confirmed by the geodetic measurements of Maupertuis, La Condamine, and others, convincing most European scientists of the superiority of Newtonian mechanics over earlier systems. In addition to his work on calculus, as a mathematician Newton contributed to the study of power series, generalised the binomial theorem to non-integer exponents, developed a method for approximating the roots of a function, and classified most of the cubic plane curves. He also demonstrated that the colours of light observed through a prism could be split into a spectrum of distinct colours, each with its own refractive index, and that white light was a composite of all the colours of the spectrum. Newton's work on light was collected in his highly influential book Opticks, first published in 1704. Newton was a fellow of Trinity College and the second Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at the University of Cambridge. He was a devout but unorthodox Christian, who privately rejected the doctrine of the Trinity and who, unusually for a member of the Cambridge faculty of the day, refused to take holy orders in the Church of England. Beyond his work on the mathematical sciences, Newton dedicated much of his time to the study of alchemy and biblical chronology, but most of his work in those areas remained unpublished until long after his death.

Galileo Galilei.passage: Galileo Galilei (15 February 1564 – 8 January 1642) was an Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer, sometimes described as a polymath, from Pisa. Galileo has been called the "father of observational astronomy", the "father of modern physics", and the "father of the scientific method". His contributions to observational astronomy include the telescopic confirmation of the phases of Venus, the discovery of the four largest satellites of Jupiter (named the Galilean moons in his honour), and the observation and analysis of sunspots. Galileo also worked in applied science and technology, inventing an improved military compass and other instruments. Galileo's championing of heliocentrism and Copernicanism was controversial during his lifetime, when most subscribed to either geocentrism or the Tychonic system. He met with opposition from astronomers, who doubted heliocentrism due to the absence of an observed stellar parallax. The matter was investigated by the Roman Inquisition in 1615, and they concluded that it could be supported as only a possibility, not an established fact. Galileo later defended his views in Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems, which appeared to attack Pope Urban VIII and thus alienated him and the Jesuits, who had both supported Galileo up until this point. He was tried by the Inquisition, found "vehemently suspect of heresy", forced to recant, and spent the rest of his life under house arrest. Stephen Hawking.passage: Stephen William Hawking (8 January 1942 – 14 March 2018) was an English theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author who was director of research at the Centre for Theoretical Cosmology at the University of Cambridge at the time of his death. He was the Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at the University of Cambridge between 1979 and 2009. Hawking was born in Oxford, England, on 8 January 1942. His father, Frank, was a medical researcher who specialized in tropical diseases, and his mother, Isobel, was a secretary. Hawking had two younger sisters, Philippa and Mary, and an adopted brother, Edward. Hawking was diagnosed with motor neuron disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), at the age of 21. The disease gradually paralyzed him over the years, and he was eventually confined to a wheelchair and had to communicate through a speech-generating device. Despite his physical limitations, Hawking made significant contributions to the field of theoretical physics. He was best known for his work on black holes, which he showed could emit radiation, now known as Hawking radiation. He also made important contributions to the study of the early universe and the nature of time. Hawking was a prolific author, publishing several popular science books, including A Brief History of Time, which has sold over 10 million copies worldwide. He also appeared in several documentaries and popular television shows, including The Simpsons and Star Trek: The Next Generation. Hawking received numerous awards and honors throughout his career, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian award in the United States. He was also a Fellow of the Royal Society and a member of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences. Hawking died on 14 March 2018 at the age of 76. His death was widely mourned, and he was remembered as one of the greatest minds of his generation.

Charles Darwin.passage: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist, geologist, and biologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution. Born in 1809 in Shrewsbury, England, Darwin was the fifth of six children. His father was a wealthy physician and financier, and his mother was the daughter of a wealthy pottery manufacturer. Darwin attended the University of Edinburgh to study medicine, but he found the lectures dull and the surgical operations gruesome. He left the university after two years and enrolled at Christ's College, Cambridge, to study theology. While at Cambridge, Darwin became interested in natural history and began collecting specimens of plants and animals. After graduating from Cambridge in 1831, Darwin was offered a position as a naturalist on the HMS Beagle, a ship that was to sail around the world on a scientific expedition. The voyage lasted five years, during which time Darwin collected specimens of plants and animals, made observations on geology and natural history, and kept a detailed journal of his experiences. Upon his return to England in 1836, Darwin began to analyze his findings and develop his theory of evolution. He spent the next 20 years studying and writing about his ideas, and in 1859 he published his most famous work, "On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection." Darwin's theory of evolution proposed that all species of organisms arise and develop through the natural selection of small, inherited variations that increase the individual's ability to compete, survive, and reproduce. This theory challenged the prevailing belief in the creation story of the Bible and caused controversy among religious leaders and scientists alike. Despite the controversy, Darwin continued to work on his theories and published several more books on evolution, including "The Descent of Man" and "The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals." He also conducted experiments on plant and animal breeding, and his work laid the foundation for the modern field of genetics. Darwin died in 1882 at the age of 73, and he was buried in Westminster Abbey, a rare honor for a scientist. His contributions to the field of biology and his theory of evolution have had a profound impact on our understanding of the natural world and continue to influence scientific research today.

Nikola Tesla.passage: Nikola Tesla (10 July 1856 – 7 January 1943) was a Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system. Born and raised in the Austrian Empire, Tesla received an advanced education in engineering and physics in the 1870s and gained practical experience in the early 1880s working in telephony and at Continental Edison in the new electric power industry. He emigrated in 1884 to the United States, where he would become a naturalized citizen. He worked for a short time at the Edison Machine Works in New York City before he struck out on his own. With the help of partners to finance and market his ideas, Tesla set up laboratories and companies in New York to develop a range of electrical and mechanical devices. His alternating current (AC) induction motor and related polyphase AC patents, licensed by Westinghouse Electric in 1888, earned him a considerable amount of money and became the cornerstone of the polyphase system which that company would eventually market. Attempting to develop inventions he could patent and market, Tesla conducted a range of experiments with mechanical oscillators/generators, electrical discharge tubes, and early X-ray imaging. He also built a wireless-controlled boat, one of the first ever exhibited. Tesla became well known as an inventor and would demonstrate his achievements to celebrities and wealthy patrons at his lab, and was noted for his showmanship at public lectures. Throughout the 1890s, Tesla pursued his ideas for wireless lighting and worldwide wireless electric power distribution in his high-voltage, high-frequency power experiments in New York and Colorado Springs. In 1893, he made pronouncements on the possibility of wireless communication with his devices. Tesla tried to put these ideas to practical use in his unfinished Wardenclyffe Tower project, an intercontinental wireless communication and power transmitter, but ran out of funding before he could complete it. After Wardenclyffe, Tesla went on to try to develop a series of inventions in the 1910s and 1920s with varying degrees of success. Having spent most of his money, he lived in a series of New York hotels, leaving behind unpaid bills. The nature of his earlier work and the pronouncements he made to the press later in life earned him the reputation of an archetypal "mad scientist" in American popular culture. Tesla died in New York City in January 1943.

Louis Pasteur.passage: Louis Pasteur (December 27, 1822 – September 28, 1895) was a French microbiologist and chemist renowned for his discoveries of the principles of vaccination, microbial fermentation, and pasteurization. He is credited with saving countless lives through his work in the field of microbiology, and his contributions to the scientific community have had a profound impact on modern medicine. Pasteur was born in Dole, France, and grew up in a family of modest means. Despite his humble beginnings, he showed an early aptitude for science and was accepted into the École Normale Supérieure in Paris, where he studied chemistry and physics. After completing his studies, he worked as a professor of chemistry at the University of Strasbourg, where he began his groundbreaking research into the nature of fermentation. Pasteur's work on fermentation led him to discover the role of microorganisms in the process, and he went on to develop the process of pasteurization, which involves heating liquids to kill harmful bacteria. This process has since been used to prevent the spread of disease and has saved countless lives. Pasteur's work on vaccination was equally groundbreaking. He developed the first vaccines for anthrax and rabies, which have since been used to prevent these deadly diseases in both humans and animals. His work on vaccination laid the foundation for modern immunology and has had a profound impact on public health. In addition to his scientific contributions, Pasteur was also a skilled administrator and diplomat. He served as the director of the École Normale Supérieure and was a member of the French Academy of Sciences. He also played a key role in negotiating the Franco-Prussian War, which helped to establish France as a major power in Europe. Pasteur's legacy continues to be felt today, as his discoveries and contributions to the field of microbiology have had a profound impact on modern medicine. His work has saved countless lives and has helped to shape the course of scientific research for generations to come.

Richard Feynman.passage: Richard Feynman was an American theoretical physicist, known for his work in the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics, the theory of quantum electrodynamics, and the physics of the superfluidity of supercooled liquid helium, as well as in particle physics for which he proposed the parton model. For his contributions to the development of quantum electrodynamics, Feynman, jointly with Julian Schwinger and Sin-Itiro Tomonaga, received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1965. He developed a widely used pictorial representation scheme for the mathematical expressions governing the behavior of subatomic particles, which later became known as Feynman diagrams. During his lifetime, Feynman became one of the best-known scientists in the world. In a 1999 poll of 130 leading physicists worldwide by the British journal Physics World he was ranked as one of the ten greatest physicists of all time. He assisted in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II and became known to a wide public in the 1980s as a member of the Rogers Commission, the panel that investigated the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster. In addition to his work in theoretical physics, Feynman has been credited with pioneering the field of quantum computing and introducing the concept of nanotechnology. He held the Richard C. Tolman professorship in theoretical physics at the California Institute of Technology. Feynman was a keen popularizer of physics through both books and lectures, notably a 1959 talk on top-down nanotechnology called There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom and The Feynman Lectures on Physics. Feynman also became known through his semi-autobiographical books, such as Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman! and What Do You Care What Other People Think?, and books written about him, such as Tuva or Bust! and Genius: The Life and Science of Richard Feynman by James Gleick.

Jane Goodall.passage: Jane Goodall is a renowned British primatologist, anthropologist, and UN Messenger of Peace. She is best known for her groundbreaking research on chimpanzees in Tanzania's Gombe Stream National Park. Goodall's work has revolutionized our understanding of primate behavior and has shed light on the complex social structures of chimpanzees. Goodall was born in London in 1934 and grew up with a love of animals. She received a degree in anthropology from the University of Cambridge in 1965 and began her research on chimpanzees in Tanzania in 1960. Goodall's research was groundbreaking in that she was the first person to observe chimpanzees in their natural habitat for an extended period of time. She spent years studying the chimpanzees' behavior, social structures, and communication methods. Goodall's research has had a profound impact on our understanding of chimpanzees and their place in the animal kingdom. She has shown that chimpanzees are capable of complex social interactions, including cooperation, competition, and even warfare. Goodall has also demonstrated that chimpanzees have a rich culture, with unique behaviors and traditions that are passed down from generation to generation. In addition to her research, Goodall has been a passionate advocate for animal welfare and conservation. She has worked tirelessly to raise awareness about the threats facing chimpanzees and other endangered species, and has been a vocal critic of the use of animals in scientific research. Goodall has received numerous awards and honors for her work, including the Kyoto Prize in 1990, the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Life Science in 2003, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2002. She has also authored several books, including "In the Shadow of Man" and "Reason for Hope." Today, Goodall continues to be a leading voice in the fight for animal welfare and conservation. She is the founder of the Jane Goodall Institute, which works to protect chimpanzees and their habitats, and she travels the world speaking about the importance of conservation and environmental stewardship. Goodall's work has inspired countless people to take action to protect the planet and its inhabitants, and her legacy will continue to inspire future generations.

Neil deGrasse Tyson.passage: Neil deGrasse Tyson is an American astrophysicist, author, and science communicator. He was born on October 5, 1958, in New York City. Tyson grew up in the Bronx and attended the Bronx High School of Science. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree in physics from Harvard University in 1980 and a Ph.D. in astrophysics from Columbia University in 1991. Tyson's research focuses on star formation, galactic evolution, and the structure of our Milky Way galaxy. He has published numerous scientific papers and has been awarded several honors for his work, including the NASA Distinguished Public Service Medal in 2004. In addition to his research, Tyson is also a prolific science communicator. He has written several popular science books, including "The Pluto Files" and "Astrophysics for People in a Hurry." He has also hosted several television shows, including "NOVA scienceNOW" and "Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey." Tyson is known for his engaging and accessible approach to science communication. He has a talent for explaining complex scientific concepts in a way that is easy for the general public to understand. He is also known for his wit and humor, which he often uses to make science more approachable and entertaining. Tyson has been a vocal advocate for science education and outreach. He has served on several government committees and advisory boards, including the NASA Advisory Council and the President's Commission on the Implementation of United States Space Exploration Policy. He has also been a frequent guest on news programs and talk shows, where he discusses science and its role in society. Despite his many accomplishments, Tyson has also faced criticism from some quarters. In particular, he has been accused of being too dismissive of alternative viewpoints and of promoting a narrow, elitist view of science. However, Tyson has defended his approach, arguing that science is a rigorous and evidence-based discipline that requires a certain level of expertise to fully understand. Overall, Neil deGrasse Tyson is a highly respected figure in the scientific community and a beloved science communicator. His work has helped to inspire a new generation of scientists and science enthusiasts, and his contributions to our understanding of the universe are sure to be remembered for years to come.

Ada Lovelace.passage: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace (10 December 1815 – 27 November 1852) was an English mathematician and writer, chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's early mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. Her notes on the engine include what is now considered to be the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine. Because of this, she is often regarded as the world's first computer programmer. Ada was the only legitimate child of the poet Lord Byron and his wife Anne Isabella Milbanke ("Annabella"), Lady Wentworth. All of Byron's other children were born out of wedlock to other women. Byron separated from his wife a month after Ada was born and left England forever four months later, eventually dying of disease in the Greek War of Independence when Ada was eight years old. Ada's mother remained bitter towards Lord Byron and promoted Ada's interest in mathematics and logic in an effort to prevent her from developing what she saw as the insanity seen in her father, but Ada remained interested in him despite this (and was, upon her eventual death, buried next to him at her request). Ada married William King in 1835. King was made Earl of Lovelace in 1838, and Ada became Countess of Lovelace. They had three children: Byron (1836–1862), Anne Isabella (called Annabella; 1837–1917), and Ralph Gordon (1839–1906). Ada died of uterine cancer in 1852 at the age of 36. As a young adult, Lovelace had a wide range of interests, including music (she was a skilled harpist), art, and science. She was also interested in mechanical devices and designed steam-powered flying machines, but was unable to make them work. In 1833, Lovelace met Charles Babbage, a mathematician and inventor who had been working on designs for a mechanical general-purpose computer called the Analytical Engine since the early 1820s. Lovelace was fascinated by the machine and began working with Babbage, translating an article about the Analytical Engine by the Italian mathematician Luigi Menabrea into English. Lovelace's notes on the article, which were longer than the article itself, included a description of how the machine could be programmed to calculate Bernoulli numbers.

Alan Turing.passage: Alan Turing was an English mathematician, logician, and computer scientist who is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. Born in London in 1912, Turing showed an early aptitude for mathematics and science, and went on to study at King's College, Cambridge, where he earned a degree in mathematics in 1934. After completing his studies, Turing began working at the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, where he played a crucial role in breaking the German Enigma code during World War II. Turing's work on the Enigma machine is widely regarded as one of the most important contributions to the Allied victory in the war. After the war, Turing continued his work in computer science, and is credited with developing the concept of a universal Turing machine, which laid the foundation for modern computing. He also made significant contributions to the field of artificial intelligence, and is known for his work on the Turing test, which is used to determine whether a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior that is indistinguishable from that of a human. Despite his many achievements, Turing's life was marked by tragedy and persecution. In 1952, he was convicted of homosexuality, which was then a criminal offense in the UK, and was forced to undergo chemical castration. Turing died two years later, at the age of 41, from an apparent suicide. In recent years, Turing has been recognized for his contributions to science and technology, and has been the subject of numerous books, films, and other works of art. In 2009, then-Prime Minister Gordon Brown issued a public apology on behalf of the British government for the way Turing was treated, and in 2013, Queen Elizabeth II granted him a posthumous pardon. Today, Turing is widely regarded as one of the most important figures in the history of computing and artificial intelligence, and his legacy continues to inspire new generations of scientists and engineers.

Max Planck.passage: Max Planck (1858-1947) was a German physicist who is widely regarded as the founder of quantum theory. Born in Kiel, Germany, Planck studied at the University of Munich and the University of Berlin before becoming a professor of theoretical physics at the University of Berlin in 1889. In 1900, Planck made a groundbreaking discovery that would change the course of physics. He proposed that energy is not continuous, but rather comes in discrete packets called quanta. This idea revolutionized the field of physics and laid the foundation for the development of quantum mechanics. Planck's work on quantum theory earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918. He continued to make significant contributions to the field throughout his career, including the development of the Planck constant, which is a fundamental constant of nature that relates the energy of a photon to its frequency. In addition to his work in physics, Planck was also a prominent figure in German academia and politics. He was a member of the Prussian Academy of Sciences and served as its president from 1930 to 1937. He was also a vocal opponent of the Nazi regime and was instrumental in helping Jewish scientists escape Germany during World War II. Planck's legacy in physics is immense, and his contributions to the field continue to be studied and built upon today. His work on quantum theory paved the way for the development of modern physics, and his constant remains a fundamental part of our understanding of the universe.

Erwin Schrödinger.passage: Erwin Schrödinger was an Austrian physicist who made significant contributions to the development of quantum mechanics. He was born on August 12, 1887, in Vienna, Austria, and died on January 4, 1961, in Vienna, Austria. Schrödinger was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 for his work on wave mechanics. Schrödinger studied physics at the University of Vienna and later at the University of Zurich, where he earned his Ph.D. in 1910. He then worked as an assistant to Max Planck at the University of Berlin and later as a professor at the University of Zurich. In 1927, he became a professor at the University of Berlin, where he worked until 1933 when he was forced to leave Germany due to the rise of the Nazi party. Schrödinger's most famous contribution to physics is his wave equation, which describes the behavior of quantum particles. The equation is a partial differential equation that describes the time evolution of a quantum system. It is used to calculate the probability of finding a particle in a particular location at a particular time. Schrödinger also developed the concept of wave-particle duality, which states that particles can exhibit both wave-like and particle-like behavior. This concept was a major breakthrough in quantum mechanics and helped to explain many of the strange phenomena observed in the quantum world. In addition to his work on quantum mechanics, Schrödinger also made significant contributions to the fields of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. He developed the concept of entropy and the Boltzmann equation, which describes the behavior of gases. Schrödinger was a prolific writer and published many books and papers on physics, philosophy, and biology. He was also interested in Eastern philosophy and wrote extensively on the subject. In conclusion, Erwin Schrödinger was a pioneering physicist who made significant contributions to the development of quantum mechanics. His wave equation and wave-particle duality concept are still widely used in physics today. Schrödinger's work on thermodynamics and statistical mechanics also had a significant impact on the field of physics.

James Clerk Maxwell.passage: James Clerk Maxwell (1831-1879) was a Scottish physicist and mathematician who is widely regarded as one of the most important scientists of the 19th century. He is best known for his work on electromagnetism, which laid the foundation for modern physics and led to the development of radio, television, and other technologies. Maxwell was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1831. He showed an early aptitude for mathematics and science, and by the age of 14 he had already published his first scientific paper. He went on to study at the University of Edinburgh and later at Cambridge University, where he became a professor of physics. Maxwell's most important contribution to science was his development of the theory of electromagnetism. He showed that electric and magnetic fields are two aspects of the same phenomenon, and that they can be described mathematically using a set of equations known as Maxwell's equations. These equations predicted the existence of electromagnetic waves, which were later discovered by Heinrich Hertz and led to the development of radio and other technologies. Maxwell also made important contributions to the study of optics, including the development of the theory of color vision and the discovery of the electromagnetic nature of light. He also worked on the kinetic theory of gases, which helped to explain the behavior of gases at the molecular level. In addition to his scientific work, Maxwell was also a skilled mathematician and philosopher. He made important contributions to the study of geometry and the philosophy of science, and he was a strong advocate for the use of mathematical models in scientific research. Maxwell died in 1879 at the age of 48, but his legacy lives on in the many scientific and technological advances that have been made possible by his work. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest scientists of all time, and his contributions to physics and mathematics continue to inspire and inform scientific research today.

Carl Sagan.passage: Carl Sagan was an American astronomer, cosmologist, astrophysicist, astrobiologist, author, science popularizer, and science communicator in astronomy and other natural sciences. He is best known for his work as a science popularizer and communicator, and for his advocacy of scientific skepticism and the scientific method. His contributions to the field of astronomy and astrophysics include research on the origins of life, the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, and the study of the atmospheres of Venus and Mars. Sagan was born in Brooklyn, New York, in 1934, and grew up in a Jewish family. He attended the University of Chicago, where he earned a bachelor's degree in physics in 1955 and a master's degree in physics in 1956. He then went on to earn a Ph.D. in astronomy and astrophysics from the University of Chicago in 1960. After completing his Ph.D., Sagan worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of California, Berkeley, and then as a professor of astronomy at Harvard University. In 1968, he became a professor of astronomy and space sciences at Cornell University, where he remained until his death in 1996. Sagan was a prolific author, writing more than 20 books on a wide range of scientific topics. His most famous book, "Cosmos," was published in 1980 and became a bestseller. The book was also turned into a television series, which was hosted by Sagan and aired on PBS. Sagan was also a vocal advocate for science education and scientific literacy. He was a frequent guest on television talk shows and news programs, and he wrote articles for popular magazines such as "Scientific American" and "Natural History." He was also a co-founder of the Planetary Society, a non-profit organization dedicated to the exploration of space and the search for extraterrestrial life. Sagan's work as a science communicator and popularizer had a profound impact on the public's understanding of science and its role in society. He was a passionate advocate for the scientific method and for the importance of evidence-based reasoning. He was also a vocal critic of pseudoscience and paranormal claims, and he worked to debunk many popular myths and misconceptions about science. Sagan's contributions to the field of astronomy and astrophysics were also significant.

Edwin Hubble.passage: Edwin Powell Hubble (November 20, 1889 – September 28, 1953) was an American astronomer who played a crucial role in establishing the field of extragalactic astronomy and is generally regarded as one of the most important observational cosmologists of the 20th century. Hubble is known for his discovery of the expansion of the universe, which he demonstrated through his observations of distant galaxies. He also played a key role in the development of the Hubble Space Telescope, which was named in his honor. Hubble was born in Marshfield, Missouri, and grew up in Wheaton, Illinois. He attended the University of Chicago, where he earned his undergraduate degree in mathematics and astronomy in 1910. He then went on to study at Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, earning his PhD in astronomy in 1917. After completing his studies, Hubble worked as a research assistant at the Mount Wilson Observatory in California, where he began his groundbreaking work on extragalactic astronomy. In 1923, he made a discovery that would change the course of astronomy: he observed a Cepheid variable star in the Andromeda Galaxy, which allowed him to calculate the distance to that galaxy. This was the first time that a galaxy beyond the Milky Way had been measured, and it showed that the universe was much larger than previously thought. Over the next several years, Hubble continued to make groundbreaking discoveries about the nature of the universe. He observed that galaxies were moving away from each other, and that the farther away a galaxy was, the faster it was moving. This led him to propose the theory of the expanding universe, which was later confirmed by other astronomers. Hubble's work had a profound impact on our understanding of the universe and the nature of space and time. He was awarded numerous honors and awards for his contributions to astronomy, including the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society and the Bruce Medal of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific. Today, Hubble's legacy lives on through the Hubble Space Telescope, which has revolutionized our understanding of the universe and provided us with stunning images of distant galaxies and other celestial objects. His work continues to inspire astronomers and scientists around the world, and his contributions to the field of astronomy will be remembered for generations to come.

Michael Faraday.passage: Michael Faraday (22 September 1791 – 25 August 1867) was an English scientist who contributed significantly to the fields of electromagnetism and electrochemistry. He is best known for his work on electromagnetic induction, which led to the development of the first electric generator. Faraday was born in Newington Butts, a suburb of London, to a poor family. He received little formal education and began working as an apprentice to a bookbinder at the age of 14. However, he was a voracious reader and taught himself about science and mathematics in his spare time. In 1812, Faraday attended a series of lectures by the chemist Humphry Davy and was so impressed that he sent Davy a letter asking for a job. Davy hired Faraday as his assistant at the Royal Institution in London, where he worked for the next 14 years. During his time at the Royal Institution, Faraday made numerous important discoveries. In 1821, he discovered electromagnetic rotation, which demonstrated the relationship between electricity and magnetism. This led to his development of the first electric motor in 1822. In 1831, Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction, which is the process by which a changing magnetic field induces an electric current in a conductor. This discovery led to the development of the first electric generator, which is the basis for all modern power generation. Faraday also made significant contributions to the field of electrochemistry. He discovered benzene in 1825 and was the first to isolate and identify several other organic compounds. He also discovered the laws of electrolysis, which describe the relationship between the amount of electricity passed through a solution and the amount of material deposited or dissolved. Faraday was a prolific writer and lecturer, and his work had a profound impact on the scientific community. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1824 and received numerous other honors throughout his career. Despite his many achievements, Faraday remained humble and dedicated to his work. He once said, "Nothing is too wonderful to be true, if it be consistent with the laws of nature." His legacy continues to inspire scientists and engineers to this day.

Werner Heisenberg.passage: Werner Heisenberg (5 December 1901 – 1 February 1976) was a German theoretical physicist and one of the key pioneers of quantum mechanics. He is best known for his uncertainty principle, which states that the more precisely the position of a particle is known, the less precisely its momentum can be known, and vice versa. Heisenberg's work laid the foundation for modern quantum mechanics and earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1932. Heisenberg was born in Würzburg, Germany, and grew up in a family of academics. He studied physics at the University of Munich, where he was influenced by the work of Max Planck and Arnold Sommerfeld. He received his doctorate in 1923 for a thesis on turbulence in fluid dynamics. In 1925, Heisenberg published his groundbreaking paper on matrix mechanics, which provided a mathematical framework for quantum mechanics. This work, along with the complementary work of Erwin Schrödinger and Paul Dirac, revolutionized the field of physics and led to a new understanding of the behavior of subatomic particles. Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, which he formulated in 1927, states that the more precisely the position of a particle is known, the less precisely its momentum can be known, and vice versa. This principle has profound implications for the behavior of subatomic particles and has been confirmed by numerous experiments. During World War II, Heisenberg worked on the German nuclear weapons program, but his efforts were ultimately unsuccessful. After the war, he became an advocate for peaceful uses of nuclear energy and was a vocal opponent of nuclear weapons. Heisenberg continued to make significant contributions to physics throughout his career, including work on the theory of relativity, the development of the S-matrix, and the discovery of the isospin symmetry of nuclear particles. He died in 1976 at the age of 74. Heisenberg's work has had a profound impact on modern physics and has influenced numerous fields, including chemistry, biology, and engineering. His uncertainty principle remains one of the most fundamental principles of quantum mechanics and has led to new insights into the behavior of subatomic particles. Heisenberg's legacy continues to inspire new generations of physicists and scientists.

The Manhattan Project..passage: The Manhattan Project was a research and development undertaking during World War II that produced the first nuclear weapons. It was led by the United States with the support of the United Kingdom and Canada. From 1942 to 1946, the project was under the direction of Major General Leslie Groves of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Nuclear physicist Robert Oppenheimer was the director of the Los Alamos Laboratory that designed the actual bombs. The Army component of the project was designated the Manhattan District; "Manhattan" gradually superseded the official codename, Development of Substitute Materials, for the entire project. Along the way, the project absorbed its earlier British counterpart, Tube Alloys. The Manhattan Project began modestly in 1939, but grew to employ more than 130,000 people and cost nearly US$2 billion (about $28 billion in 2016 dollars). Over 90% of the cost was for building factories and producing the fissionable materials, with less than 10% for development and production of the weapons. Research and production took place at more than 30 sites across the United States, the United Kingdom, and Canada. The project was successfully completed on July 16, 1945, when the first atomic bomb was detonated at the Trinity test site in New Mexico.

Bertrand Russell..passage: Bertrand Russell was a British philosopher, logician, mathematician, historian, writer, social critic, political activist, and Nobel laureate. At various points in his life, Russell considered himself a liberal, a socialist and a pacifist, although he also confessed that his sceptical nature had led him to feel that he had "never been any of these things, in any profound sense." Russell was born in Monmouthshire into one of the most prominent aristocratic families in the United Kingdom. In the early 20th century, Russell led the British "revolt against idealism". He is considered one of the founders of analytic philosophy along with his predecessor Gottlob Frege, colleague G. E. Moore and protégé Ludwig Wittgenstein. He is widely held to be one of the 20th century's premier logicians. With A. N. Whitehead he wrote Principia Mathematica, an attempt to create a logical basis for mathematics. His philosophical essay "On Denoting" has been considered a "paradigm of philosophy". His work has had a considerable influence on mathematics, logic, set theory, linguistics, artificial intelligence, cognitive science, computer science (see type theory and type system) and philosophy, especially the philosophy of language, epistemology and metaphysics.

She married fellow scientist Pierre Curie in 1895, and together they discovered the elements polonium and radium. Venus..passage: Venus is the second planet from the Sun, orbiting it every 224.7 Earth days. It has the longest rotation period (243 days) of any planet in the Solar System and rotates in the opposite direction to most other planets. It has no natural satellite. It is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty. It is the brightest natural object in the night sky after the Moon, reaching an apparent magnitude of −4.6, bright enough to cast shadows. Because Venus is an inferior planet from Earth, it never appears to venture far from the Sun: its elongation reaches a maximum of 47.8°. Venus reaches its maximum brightness shortly before sunrise or shortly after sunset, for which reason it has been referred to by ancient cultures as the Morning Star or Evening Star. Venus is a terrestrial planet and is sometimes called Earth's "sister planet" because of their similar size, mass, proximity to the Sun, and bulk composition. It is radically different from Earth in other respects. It has the densest atmosphere of the four terrestrial planets, consisting of more than 96% carbon dioxide. The atmospheric pressure at the planet's surface is 92 times that of Earth, or roughly the pressure found 900 m (3,000 ft) underwater on Earth. Venus is by far the hottest planet in the Solar System, with a mean surface temperature of 735 K (462 °C; 863 °F), even though Mercury is closer to the Sun. Venus is shrouded by an opaque layer of highly reflective clouds of sulfuric acid, preventing its surface from being seen from space in visible light. It may have had water oceans in the past, but these would have vaporized as the temperature rose due to a runaway greenhouse effect. The water has probably photodissociated, and the free hydrogen has been swept into interplanetary space by the solar wind because of the lack of a planetary magnetic field. Venus's surface is a dry desertscape interspersed with slab-like rocks and periodically refreshed by volcanism.

Copernicanism..passage: Copernicanism is a theory that was proposed by the Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus in the 16th century. The theory challenged the prevailing belief that the Earth was the center of the universe and instead proposed that the Sun was at the center, with the Earth and other planets orbiting around it. This idea, known as the heliocentric model, was a major shift in thinking about the cosmos and had significant implications for astronomy, physics, and philosophy. Copernicus developed his theory over many years, drawing on observations of the movements of the planets and stars. He published his ideas in his book "De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium" (On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres) in 1543, just before his death. The book was initially met with skepticism and resistance, but over time it gained acceptance and became a cornerstone of modern astronomy. Copernicanism had a profound impact on the way people thought about the universe and their place in it. It challenged the idea that humans were at the center of creation and instead suggested that they were just one small part of a vast and complex system. This idea had implications for religion, philosophy, and science, and it paved the way for further discoveries and advancements in these fields. Today, Copernicanism is widely accepted as the correct model of the solar system, and it continues to inspire scientists and thinkers around the world. Its legacy can be seen in everything from space exploration to our understanding of the fundamental laws of physics.

Wardenclyffe Tower..passage: Wardenclyffe Tower (also known as the Tesla Tower) was a wireless transmission station designed and built by Nikola Tesla in Shoreham, New York in the early 20th century. The tower was intended to transmit wireless messages, telephony and even power without the use of wires. Tesla believed that this technology would revolutionize communication and bring about a new era of global connectivity. The tower was constructed between 1901 and 1905, and was 187 feet tall with a diameter of 68 feet at its base. It was designed to transmit signals across the Atlantic Ocean, but due to financial difficulties, the project was never completed. In 1917, the tower was dismantled and sold for scrap metal to pay off Tesla's debts. Despite its failure, the Wardenclyffe Tower remains an important symbol of Tesla's visionary ideas and his contributions to the field of electrical engineering. The tower has inspired numerous works of art and literature, and has become a popular destination for tourists and Tesla enthusiasts. In recent years, efforts have been made to preserve the remaining structures on the site and turn it into a museum dedicated to Tesla's life and work.

Wardenclyffe..passage: Wardenclyffe Tower (1901–1917), also known as the Tesla Tower, was an early experimental wireless transmission station designed and built by Nikola Tesla in Shoreham, New York in 1901–1902. Tesla intended to transmit messages, telephony and even facsimile images across the Atlantic to England and to ships at sea based on his theories of using the Earth to conduct the signals. His decision to scale up the facility and add his ideas of wireless power transmission to better compete with Guglielmo Marconi's radio-based telegraph system was met with financial problems. Wardenclyffe Tower was never fully operational, and the site was abandoned in 1917. The tower was dismantled in 1917 and 1918, and the property was sold to pay the debts. Today, the site is occupied by a photography company and a Superfund cleanup site.

French Academy of Sciences..passage: The French Academy of Sciences (French: Académie des sciences) is a learned society, founded in 1666 by Louis XIV at the suggestion of Jean-Baptiste Colbert, to encourage and protect the spirit of French scientific research. It was at the forefront of scientific developments in Europe in the 17th and 18th centuries, and is one of the earliest Academies of Sciences. Today, it is one of the five Academies of the Institut de France. The Academy of Sciences owes its origin to Colbert's plan to create a general academy. He chose a small group of scholars who met regularly in his residence, the King's library, to discuss scientific topics. The first members were appointed in 1666, and the Academy was officially established in 1667. The Academy's mission was to promote scientific research and to encourage the dissemination of scientific knowledge. It was also responsible for the publication of scientific works, and for the organization of scientific meetings and conferences. The Academy played a key role in the development of French science, and its members included some of the most important scientists of the time, such as Pierre-Simon Laplace, Antoine Lavoisier, and Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon. Today, the Academy continues to play an important role in French science, and its members are among the most distinguished scientists in the world.

Europe..passage: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere and mostly in the Eastern Hemisphere. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. It comprises the westernmost part of Eurasia. Since around 1850, Europe is most commonly considered to be separated from Asia by the watershed divides of the Ural and Caucasus Mountains, the Ural River, the Caspian and Black Seas, and the waterways of the Turkish Straits. Although the term "continent" implies physical geography, the land border is somewhat arbitrary and has moved since its first conception in classical antiquity. The division of Eurasia into two continents reflects East-West cultural, linguistic, and ethnic differences, some of which vary on a spectrum rather than with a sharp dividing line. The border does not follow political boundaries, with Turkey, Russia, and Kazakhstan being transcontinental countries. Europe covers about 10,180,000 square kilometres (3,930,000 sq mi), or 2% of the Earth's surface (6.8% of land area), making it the second smallest continent (using the seven-continent model). Politically, Europe is divided into about fifty sovereign states of which the Russian Federation is the largest and most populous, spanning 39% of the continent and comprising 15% of its population. Europe had a total population of about 741 million (about 11% of the world population) as of 2018.

Franco-Prussian War..passage: The Franco-Prussian War was a conflict between France and Prussia that lasted from 1870 to 1871. The war was sparked by tensions between the two nations over the issue of German unification, which had been a topic of debate for many years. Prussia, under the leadership of Chancellor Otto von Bismarck, had been working to unify the various German states under its control, while France saw this as a threat to its own power and influence in Europe. The war began in July 1870, when France declared war on Prussia. The French army, led by Emperor Napoleon III, initially had some success, but was ultimately defeated by the superior Prussian forces. The decisive battle of the war took place at Sedan in September 1870, where the French army was surrounded and forced to surrender. Following the defeat at Sedan, the French government collapsed and a new government was formed, which sued for peace. The resulting Treaty of Frankfurt, signed in May 1871, saw France cede the provinces of Alsace and Lorraine to Germany, and pay a large indemnity to Prussia. The Franco-Prussian War had a significant impact on European politics and the balance of power on the continent. It marked the emergence of Germany as a major European power, and led to the eventual unification of Germany under Bismarck's leadership. The war also had a profound impact on France, leading to a period of political instability and social unrest that lasted for many years.

She died of uterine cancer at the age of 36. Bletchley Park..passage: Bletchley Park is a country house and estate in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, England that became the principal centre of Allied code-breaking during the Second World War. The mansion was constructed during the years following 1883 for the English financier and politician Sir Herbert Samuel Leon in the Victorian Gothic, Tudor, and Dutch Baroque styles, on the site of older buildings of the same name. During World War II, the estate housed the Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS), which regularly penetrated the secret communications of the Axis Powers – most importantly the German Enigma and Lorenz ciphers. The official historian of World War II British Intelligence has written that the "Ultra" intelligence produced at Bletchley shortened the war by two to four years, and that without it the outcome of the war would have been uncertain. The site also housed Station X, a secret radio intercept station.

Max Planck..passage: Max Planck was a German physicist who is widely regarded as the founder of quantum theory. Born in Kiel in 1858, Planck studied at the University of Munich and the University of Berlin before becoming a professor of theoretical physics at the University of Berlin in 1889. In 1900, he proposed a revolutionary idea that energy is not continuous, but rather comes in discrete packets called quanta. Dirac was also known for his work on quantum electrodynamics, which describes the interaction between charged particles and electromagnetic fields. He developed a mathematical framework for the theory that was later refined by Richard Feynman and others. Dirac was a highly influential figure in the development of modern physics, and his work continues to inspire new research in the field today.
